sourcesContent:
import React from 'react' function JsEs5_5() { return (

Array

In JavaScript, an array is a data structure that allows you to store multiple values in a single variable. An array is declared using square brackets, and its elements are separated by commas.

Example 
  
    {' // An array of numbers\nvar numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];\n\n// An array of strings\nvar fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"];'}
Array Length

The length property of an array returns the number of elements in the array.

Example 
  
    {'var numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];\nconsole.log(numbers.length); // Output: 5'}
Array Methods

Arrays in JavaScript have built-in methods that can be used to manipulate the array data. Some commonly used array methods are:

push(): adds one or more elements to the end of an array
pop(): removes the last element from an array
shift(): removes the first element from an array
unshift(): adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array
splice(): adds or removes elements from an array at a specified index
slice(): returns a new array that contains a portion of an existing array
join(): joins all elements of an array into a string
concat(): concatenates two or more arrays
Example: 
  
    {' var numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];\nnumbers.push(6); // adds 6 to the end of the array\nconsole.log(numbers); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]'}
  

  
    {'var fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"];\nfruits.pop(); // removes the last element from the array\nconsole.log(fruits); // Output: ["apple", "banana"]'}
  

  
    {' var colors = ["red", "green", "blue"];\ncolors.shift(); // removes the first element from the array\nconsole.log(colors); // Output: ["green", "blue"]'}
  

  
    {'var cars = ["BMW", "Audi", "Mercedes"];\ncars.unshift("Toyota", "Honda"); // adds two elements to the beginning of the array\nconsole.log(cars);//Output:["Toyota","Honda","BMW","Audi","Mercedes"]'}
) } export default JsEs5_5;
